ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Rotherham - Page
ai_page.body:
Making changes to your council home

Alterations and Permissions: What You Can and Cannot Do

Below are lists of examples of alterations and permission requirements. This will help you plan your improvements smoothly.

Outright Permission

Outright Permission can be given through your Area Housing Officer for the alterations below:

  • Battery operated smoke alarms
  • Clothesline and clothes posts (within the boundary their garden)
  • Curtain rails
  • Door handles and cupboard handles
  • External post boxes
  • Installing blinds
  • Installing Key Safe outside own door (not on exterior of communal blocks)
  • Shelves
  • Having a water meter fitted

An asbestos test will be required in most cases - the Officer working with you on the alteration will be able to determine this and the job will be referred to the Asbestos Team to conduct a survey. The results will be discussed with you as the alteration request progresses. Please be aware that asbestos removal may mean that your alteration is delayed, but work cannot take place before this is resolved. There is no cost to the tenant if a survey is required. However, tenant may be required to pay for wall and ceiling artexing removals.

Outright Refusal

The Council will not provide permission for the following works due to the impacts of these works on future occupation or sale of property, noise issues, fire safety compliance, health, safety and environment compliance, and visual appearance.

  • Artexing walls and ceilings
  • Driveways for upper floor flats
  • Extra locks to windows and additional locks and latches
  • Installing cat flaps
  • Installing metal gates directly outside a door
  • Key safe (communal blocks)
  • Laminate floor on first floor of houses or flats
  • Loft conversions in flats
  • Painting kitchen cupboards and tiles
  • Removing an electric fire to install a gas fire
  • Wood burners, open fires, or any muti-fuel appliances
  • Swimming pools
  • Wind turbine

ai_business_case.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Rotherham - Business Case
ai_business_case.letter:
To the CEO,

As the web usability lead reviewing the recent customer feedback and site content, I recommend the following targeted improvements to enhance service efficiency, reduce unnecessary contact, and streamline our processes—ultimately saving the council money.

**Positive Feedback and Recognition**  
The current information clearly explains what types of flat improvements tenants can request and outlines the approval criteria effectively. Well done to the web team for providing clear insights into permissible alterations!

**Areas for Improvement and Specific Recommendations**  
While the existing content is informative, customers like David expressed confusion around the actual submission process and response times. Addressing these issues can significantly improve user experience and operational efficiency.

1. **Add a Clear, Step-by-Step Submission Guide**  
- **Current Issue:** The lack of explicit instructions on how to submit online requests may lead to uncertainty or repeated inquiries.  
- **Proposed Solution:** Develop a dedicated "How to Apply" section with numbered steps, visual aids, or a flow diagram that walks users through accessing the online form, uploading documents/photos, and submitting the application.  
- **Impact:** This reduces confusion, decreases inbound queries, and speeds up processing times—saving staff hours and reducing administrative costs.

2. **Include a Direct Link and Clear Access Instructions for the Application Form**  
- **Current Issue:** No direct link or clear access points make it slightly cumbersome for users to find the application form.  
- **Proposed Solution:** Embed a prominent, clickable button labelled "Apply for Flat Improvements" on the relevant page, along with simple instructions (e.g., "Click here to start your online request").  
- **Impact:** Facilitates seamless user flow, encourages timely submissions, and prevents users from abandoning their requests due to navigational difficulties.

3. **Communicate Clear Response Timeframes and Process Updates**  
- **Current Issue:** Vague expectations about delays (e.g., asbestos testing, approvals) can cause user anxiety and follow-up inquiries.  
- **Proposed Solution:** Provide a standard response time expectation (e.g., "Most requests are reviewed within 10 working days") and outline how users will be kept informed (email updates, status tracking).  
- **Impact:** Improves transparency, enhances trust, and reduces manual follow-up calls, allowing staff to focus on processing requests rather than answering status inquiries.

**Conclusion**  
Implementing a straightforward, step-by-step online submission flow, enhanced with direct call-to-action links and transparent timelines, will vastly improve the user experience. This will decrease administrative overhead, reduce delays caused by user confusion, and promote quicker, more independent engagement from tenants. Overall, these improvements will drive greater service efficiency and represent a cost-effective way to meet the needs of our council tenants.

Respectfully,

[Your Name]  
Web Usability Lead
